title: How & why did Czechoslovakia lose the Ruthenian region following WWII? - Quora

response.answer_text: The original Czechoslovak intention was to restore pre-war borders and it was never questioned by USSR. On 8 May 1944, USSR and Czechoslovakia signed a treaty concerning the relationship between the Czechoslovak administration and the Supreme Command of the Red Army. According to this treaty, all power had to be in the hands of Czechoslovak authorities immediately after the end of military operations. In October 1944, the Red Army started liberation of Subcarpathian Ruthenia. The Czechoslovak government-in-exile sent there a delegation to administer the region (per the treaty). However, there was a latent conflict between pro-Czechoslovak and pro-Soviet movement supported by Soviet bodies. On 26 November 1944, a committee, led by a Soviet agent Ivan Turyanitsa proclaimed the will of people to join the Soviet Ukraine. USSR declared that it would not act against the will of people. Czechoslovak Communists quickly agreed and the rest accepted a new situation. Czechoslovakia and USSR signed a treaty about Subcarpathian Ruthenia, resp. Carpathian Ukraine on 29 June 1945.

Short answer: because Stalin said so. Long answer: Subcarpathian Ruthenia was lost during First Vienna Award in 1938 to Hungary, as the rest of southern Slovakia. When in october 1944 Red Army pushed into the region, according to agreement that Czechoslovakia would reemerge in pre-1938 borders, government-in-exile in London despatched delegation there to prepare elections and mobilize liberated local population into Czechoslovak army. Mobilization proclamation was issued on 30. october, Soviet forces there prevented both publishing and posting of it. They also prevented the delegation from working with local comitees, instead Soviets started to organize locals and biggest relevance was given to Communist. On 19. november local Communists created resolution that region is leaving Czechoslovakia and joining Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic. And Czechoslovak delegation was ordered by Soviets to leave. How it even got into Czechoslovakia in the first place, since there are no Czechs or Slovaks living?
